elements.content: Two novel vanadogermanates [Cd­(en)­(H2O)2]­[Cd­(en)2]­[Cd­(en)]­{[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]}·2H2O (1) and [Cd­(en)3]­[Cd­(en)]2{[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42(OH)6]}·10H2O (2, en = ethylenediamine) have been hydrothermally synthesized and structurally characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectroscopy, powder X-ray diffractions, thermogravimetric analysis, UV–vis spectroscopy, and single-crystal X-ray diffractions. Structural analysis reveals that the Ge–V–O cluster anions in the two compounds are derived from the classical saturated {V18O42} cluster by replacing four VO5 square pyramids with four Ge2O7 groups. Especially, the Ge–V–O cluster anion in 2 is a new configuration of Ge–V–O clusters with four Ge2O7 groups and first reported in this work. 1 is the first 1-dimensional (1-D) chain based on the linkage of centrosymmetric dimeric clusters {[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]}2 12– and trinuclearity [Cd3O4(en)4(H2O)2]2– complexes. 2 is an unprecedented 2-D network built from unique {[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42(OH)6]}8– clusters and 1-D coordination chains {Cd3O2(en)5}2+. Magnetic measurements illustrate that these compounds have overall antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between metal ions.

elements.content: Reactions of NH4VO3, GeO2, CdCl2·2.5H2O and en (en = ethylenediamine) under hydrothermal conditions have led to the formation of two kinds of di-Cd-substituted V−Ge−O clusters: α-[(en)2Cd2Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]12- and γ-[(en)2Cd2Ge8V12O43(OH)5]5-. Using the commonly observed α-isomer as building blocks and further connected by trinuclearity complexes, an infinite 1-dimensional chain [Cd­(en)­(H2O)2]­[Cd­(en)2]­[Cd­(en)]­{[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]}·2H2O (1) can be obtained. The γ-isomer was first reported in this work, and it can be further linked by 1-dimensional coordination chains to generate an unprecedented 2-dimensional network [Cd­(en)3]­[Cd­(en)]2{[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42(OH)6]}·10H2O (2).

Using the commonly observed α-isomer as building blocks and further connected by trinuclearity complexes, an infinite 1-dimensional chain [Cd(en)(H2O)2][Cd(en)2][Cd(en)]{[Cd(en)]2[Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]}⋅2H2O (1) can be obtained. elements.content: As an important subclass of polyoxometalates, polyoxovanadates (POVs) have been attracting persistent attention for not only their intriguing structural diversities but also their potential applications in various areas such as magnetism, catalysis, and medicine. Compared with molybdenum, tungsten, and niobium, vanadium can easily form various building units such as VO4 tetrahedra, VO5 square pyramids, and VO6 octahedra due to its flexible coordination geometry and variable oxidation state characteristics, resulting in some classical POVs such as lindqvist-type {V6O19}, {V10V28}, and {V18O42}. Except for these POVs, an important strategy to broaden the research field of POVs is to introduce heteroatoms into the system. It is believed that the introduction of appropriate heteroatoms would bring novel cluster geometries and endow the new POVs with new functionalities. Recently, intense research on POVs mainly focused on the introduction of group 15 elements (As3+ and Sb3+) into the skeleton of the {V18O42} cluster, where the [As2O5]/[Sb2O5] dimers, formed by two vertex-sharing [AsO3]/[SbO3] trigonal pyramids, are substituted for the VO5 groups on the {V18O42} shell, giving rise to a large number of As–V–O and Sb–V–O clusters with general formula {M2n V18‑n O42(X)} (M = As, Sb; n = 2, 3, 4; X = H2O, Cl–, SO3 2–). However, these As/Sb-substituted POVs are not good building blocks in making extended structures because of the weak coordination capability of As3+/ Sb3+ lone electron pairs. It would be different if Si4+/Ge4+ were used instead of As3+/Sb3+. It has been proven that the [Si2O7]/[Ge2O7] dimers made up of two SiO4/GeO4 tetrahedra are superior to [As2O5]/[Sb2O5] in making extended structures. This is because the [Si2O7]/[Ge2O7] dimers can increase the likelihood of producing extended structures through self-condensation of [Si2O7]/[Ge2O7] units or offering good donors for electrophilic metal ions. Lately, some interesting vanadosilicates/vanadogermanates with extended structures have been made. For example, Hu’s group reported two Ge–V–O cluster-based frameworks based on [Ge4V16O47] units and four extended vanadosilicates/vanadogermanates containing [V15Si6O42(OH)6(Cl)]/[V15Ge6O42(OH)6(Cl)] building blocks. More recently, a series of 3-dimensional (3-D) frameworks based on vanadogermanate clusters have been reported by Yang and co-workers. Lately, a vanadogermanate-based dimer containing α-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} clusters has been found by Liu’s group. Nevertheless, the number of vanadosilicates/vanadogermanates is still very limited, compared with abundant extended structures based on polyoxotungstate and polymolybdate clusters.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As an important subclass of polyoxometalates, polyoxovanadates (POVs) have been attracting persistent attention for not only their intriguing structural diversities but also their potential applications in various areas such as magnetism, catalysis, and medicine. Compared with molybdenum, tungsten, and niobium, vanadium can easily form various building units such as VO4 tetrahedra, VO5 square pyramids, and VO6 octahedra due to its flexible coordination geometry and variable oxidation state characteristics, resulting in some classical POVs such as lindqvist-type {V6O19}, {V10V28}, and {V18O42}. Except for these POVs, an important strategy to broaden the research field of POVs is to introduce heteroatoms into the system. It is believed that the introduction of appropriate heteroatoms would bring novel cluster geometries and endow the new POVs with new functionalities. Recently, intense research on POVs mainly focused on the introduction of group 15 elements (As3+ and Sb3+) into the skeleton of the {V18O42} cluster, where the [As2O5]/[Sb2O5] dimers, formed by two vertex-sharing [AsO3]/[SbO3] trigonal pyramids, are substituted for the VO5 groups on the {V18O42} shell, giving rise to a large number of As-V-O and Sb-V-O clusters with general formula {M2n V18-n O42(X)} (M = As, Sb; n = 2, 3, 4; X = H2O, Cl-, SO3 2-). However, these As/Sb-substituted POVs are not good building blocks in making extended structures because of the weak coordination capability of As3+/ Sb3+ lone electron pairs. It would be different if Si4+/Ge4+ were used instead of As3+/Sb3+. It has been proven that the [Si2O7]/[Ge2O7] dimers made up of two SiO4/GeO4 tetrahedra are superior to [As2O5]/[Sb2O5] in making extended structures. This is because the [Si2O7]/[Ge2O7] dimers can increase the likelihood of producing extended structures through self-condensation of [Si2O7]/[Ge2O7] units or offering good donors for electrophilic metal ions. Lately, some interesting vanadosilicates/vanadogermanates with extended structures have been made. For example, Hu's group reported two Ge-V-O cluster-based frameworks based on [Ge4V16O47] units and four extended vanadosilicates/vanadogermanates containing [V15Si6O42(OH)6(Cl)]/[V15Ge6O42(OH)6(Cl)] building blocks. More recently, a series of 3-dimensional (3-D) frameworks based on vanadogermanate clusters have been reported by Yang and co-workers. Lately, a vanadogermanate-based dimer containing α-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} clusters has been found by Liu's group. Nevertheless, the number of vanadosilicates/vanadogermanates is still very limited, compared with abundant extended structures based on polyoxotungstate and polymolybdate clusters.

elements.content: Furthermore, it is expected that the second transition metal (TM) ions can further be incorporated in POV skeleton, which may not only generate a new class of materials with novel topology but also lead to new properties. However, few investigations have been carried out on TM-substituted POVs because of the lack of lacunary of POV precursors. Previously, Yang and co-workers have explored the As–V–O synthetic system in the presence of second TM ions and made some mono- and di-TM-substituted clusters (TM = Ni, Zn, Cd) under hydrothermal conditions. Later, Wang’s group also made some Zn/Cd-substituted As–V–O clusters with mixed organoamine ligands under similar conditions. In contrast, TM-substituted vanadosilicates/vanadogermanates are very rare. With the aim of making novel TM-substituted vanadogermanates, herein, we report the syntheses, structures, and properties of two new di-Cd-substituted vanadogermanates [Cd­(en)­(H2O)2]­[Cd­(en)2]­[Cd­(en)]­{[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8-V12O42.5(OH)5]}·2H2O (1) and [Cd­(en)3]­[Cd­(en)]2{[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42(OH)6]}·10H2O (2). 1 is the first 1-dimensional (1-D) vanadogermanate based on the linkage of centrosymmetric dimeric Ge–V–O clusters {[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]}2 12‑ and trinuclearity [Cd3O4(en)4(H2O)2]2– complexes. 2 is an unprecedented 2-D network built from unique Ge–V–O γ-{[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42(OH)6]}8– clusters and 1-D coordination chains {Cd3O2(en)5}2+.

elements.content: All reagents of analytical grade were purchased from commercial sources and without any further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out with a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra (4000–400 cm–1) were recorded on a Nicoletis 10 spectrometer with KBr pellets. TGA measurements were performed up to 1000 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a flowing N2 atmosphere with a NETZSCH PC409 simultaneous thermal analyzer. PXRD patterns of the samples were analyzed by a computer automated diffractometer (Bruker D8 Advance) equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) at room temperature. The 2θ range is 5–50° with a step of 0.02°. The magnetic susceptibility data were measured with a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID VSM magnetometer in an external magnetic field of 1 kOe at 2–300 K.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

All reagents of analytical grade were purchased from commercial sources and without any further purification. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were carried out with a Vario EL III elemental analyzer. FT-IR spectra (4000-400 cm-1) were recorded on a Nicoletis 10 spectrometer with KBr pellets. TGA measurements were performed up to 1000 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min under a flowing N2 atmosphere with a NETZSCH PC409 simultaneous thermal analyzer. PXRD patterns of the samples were analyzed by a computer automated diffractometer (Bruker D8 Advance) equipped with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å) at room temperature. The 2θ range is 5-50° with a step of 0.02°. The magnetic susceptibility data were measured with a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID VSM magnetometer in an external magnetic field of 1 kOe at 2-300 K.

elements.content: A mixture of NH4VO3 (0.0234 g, 0.20 mmol), GeO2 (0.0376 g, 0.36 mmol), CdCl2·2.5H2O (0.0228 g, 0.10 mmol), en (0.1 mL), and H2O (5 mL) was stirred for 0.5 h. Then it was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless stell autoclave and sealed. The mixture was heated at 170 °C for 4 days and then cooled to room temperature. Brown flake-shaped crystals were recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water, and dried at ambient temperature (yield: 0.0412 g, 31% on the base of GeO2). elements.content: X-ray diffraction data for 1 and 2 were collected on a MM007-Saturn724+ CCD diffractometer at 296(2) K equipped with a fine focus, 2.0 kW sealed tube X-ray source (Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å) operating at 50 kV and 30 mA. The program SADABS was used for the absorption correction. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares methods using the SHELX 2013 program package. All hydrogen atoms attached to carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen atoms were geometrically placed. The final formulas of 1 and 2 were determined by the combination of single-crystal X-ray diffraction with elemental analysis and thermogravimetric analysis. Crystallographic data and structure refinements for 1 and 2 are summarized in . CCDC 1516072–1516073 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge from The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif.

The molecular structure of 1 is made up of one di-Cd-substituted Ge–V–O cluster {[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O43(OH)5]}7– (1a, a,b), one [Cd­(en)­(H2O)2]2+ group, one [Cd­(en)2]2+ unit, one [Cd­(en)]2+ fragment, and four lattice water molecules. Two [Cd­(en)2]2+ groups take the place of two VO2+ groups located between the Ge2O7 units of the reported {Ge8V14O42(OH)8} polyanion with rhombicuboctahedral topology, generating a new {[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O43(OH)5]}7– cluster. The V–O/Ge–O bond lengths of terminal O atoms are in the range of 1.601(2)–1.633(4)/1.685(5)–1.744(5) Å, and for the bridging O atoms fall in the range of 1.907(1)–2.022(2)/ 1.689(1)–1.790(3) Å. The assignment of oxidation states for the Ge and V atoms is confirmed by BVS calculations, which give average valences of 4.03 and 4.08 for Ge and V, respectively (Table S1). Three unique Cd2+ ions (Cd3, Cd4, Cd5) besides 1a exhibit two different coordination geometries: distorted trigonal bipyramid CdO3N2 (Cd3) and slightly distorted octahedra CdO2N4 (Cd4) and CdO4N2 (Cd5). The Cd3 ion is defined by three O atom from two 1a cluster and two N atoms of one en ligand. The Cd4 ion is coordinated by two O atoms from two adjacent 1a clusters and four N atoms of two en ligands, whereas the Cd5 ion is surrounded by two O atoms from two adjacent 1a clusters, two coordinated water ligands and one en molecule. The bond lengths of Cd–N and Cd–O vary from 2.268(2) to 2.377(0) and 2.197(3) to 2.836(4) Å, respectively. The Cd3, Cd4, and Cd5 ions are further interlinked by bridging O atoms to form a trinuclearity cluster [Cd3O4(en)4(H2O)2]2–. The structure of [Cd3O4(en)4(H2O)2]2– can be considered as one CdO2N4 octahedron linked with one CdO3N2 trigonal bipyramid through sharing one edge, and which is further connected by one CdO4N2 octahedron through sharing one vertex (c).

elements.content: An interesting structural feature of 1 is that 1a can elaborately self-assemble into a dimeric building block. In 1, the two neighboring 1a clusters were self-connected through sharing one vertex of GeO4 tetrahedra (d), leading to the formation of a centrosymmetric dimer {[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]}2 12–. The size of the {[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]}2 dimer is about 2.34 × 1.15 × 1.15 nm3 (Figure S1, measured between two opposite polyhedra). Worthy of mention is the further linkage of these nanoscale dimers. As shown in d, each {[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]}2 12– dimer joined with two neighboring ones by four [Cd3O4(en)4(H2O)2]2– clusters through sharing Cd–O–V/Cd–O–Ge bonds, resulting in an infinite 1-D chain. To the best of our knowledge, such a hybrid chain based on the linkage of centrosymmetric dimeric Ge–V–O clusters and trinuclearity TM clusters has not been reported in vanadogermanates so far.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that 2 exhibits a 2-D layer structure. Its asymmetric unit contains one di-Cd-substituted Ge–V–O cluster {[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42(OH)6]}6– (2a, a,b), three unique Cd2+ ions (Cd3, Cd4, Cd5), five en ligands, and ten lattice water molecules (Figure S2). 2a is a new type of acentric Ge–V–O cluster, which can be considered as an isomer of 1a. Compared with 1a, the structure of 2a can be viewed as one of two perpendicular {V2O6(Ge2O7)2[Cd­(en)]}14– groups on the top, and the bottom of the eight-ring based on VO5 square pyramids is rotated by about 45° along the vertical axis of the eight-ring. Such a configuration has not been reported in the Ge–V–O cluster until now, to the best of our knowledge. The oxidation state of all V atoms in 2a is in the range of 3.98 to 4.21, and that of the eight Ge atoms ranges from 3.97 to 4.11, on the basis of BVS calculations (Table S2). Three unique Cd2+ ions adopt two different coordination geometries. The Cd4 ion is octahedrally coordinated by two terminal O atoms of two VO5 square pyramids from two neighboring clusters and four N atoms from two bridging en ligands and one chelating en molecule (c). It is noteworthy that the en ligands in 2 have two coordination modes, including didentate chelating mode and linear bridging mode, which is obviously different from that in 1. The Cd3 and Cd5 ions have a distorted square-pyramidal environment defined by two O atoms of two GeO4 tetrahedra from two clusters and three N atoms from one chelating en ligand and one bridging en ligand (c). It is interesting that these square-pyramidal coordinated Cd2+ ions (Cd3 and Cd5) are joined with their symmetry-related ones to form dinuclearity [Cd2O2(en)2] fragments which are further connected by bridging [CdO2(en)3]2– groups (Cd4) to form an infinite 1-D zigzag chain {Cd3O2(en)5}2+ (c). The Cd–O and Cd–N bond distances in the 1-D chain vary from 2.196(2) to 2.378(4)­Å and 2.229(3) to 2.371(5) Å, respectively. The most striking structural feature of 2 is the further linkage of 1-D zigzag chains by 2a clusters. As shown in d, two neighboring parallel 1-D chains can be interlinked by 2a through sharing four bridging O atoms, resulting in the formation of a 2-D zigzag layer (e,f). These 2-D layers stacked in parallel along the a axis with the interlayer distance of about 3.0 Å (Figure S3), and the interspace is filled with lattice water molecules.

Crystal Structure of 2 

Single crystal X-ray structural analysis reveals that 2 exhibits a 2-D layer structure. Its asymmetric unit contains one di-Cd-substituted Ge-V-O cluster {[Cd(en)]2[Ge8V12O42(OH)6]}6- (2a, a,b), three unique Cd2+ ions (Cd3, Cd4, Cd5), five en ligands, and ten lattice water molecules (Figure S2). 2a is a new type of acentric Ge-V-O cluster, which can be considered as an isomer of 1a. Compared with 1a, the structure of 2a can be viewed as one of two perpendicular {V2O6(Ge2O7)2[Cd(en)]}14- groups on the top, and the bottom of the eight-ring based on VO5 square pyramids is rotated by about 45° along the vertical axis of the eight-ring. Such a configuration has not been reported in the Ge-V-O cluster until now, to the best of our knowledge. The oxidation state of all V atoms in 2a is in the range of 3.98 to 4.21, and that of the eight Ge atoms ranges from 3.97 to 4.11, on the basis of BVS calculations (Table S2). Three unique Cd2+ ions adopt two different coordination geometries. The Cd4 ion is octahedrally coordinated by two terminal O atoms of two VO5 square pyramids from two neighboring clusters and four N atoms from two bridging en ligands and one chelating en molecule (c). It is noteworthy that the en ligands in 2 have two coordination modes, including didentate chelating mode and linear bridging mode, which is obviously different from that in 1. The Cd3 and Cd5 ions have a distorted square-pyramidal environment defined by two O atoms of two GeO4 tetrahedra from two clusters and three N atoms from one chelating en ligand and one bridging en ligand (c). It is interesting that these square-pyramidal coordinated Cd2+ ions (Cd3 and Cd5) are joined with their symmetry-related ones to form dinuclearity [Cd2O2(en)2] fragments which are further connected by bridging [CdO2(en)3]2- groups (Cd4) to form an infinite 1-D zigzag chain {Cd3O2(en)5}2+ (c). The Cd-O and Cd-N bond distances in the 1-D chain vary from 2.196(2) to 2.378(4)Å and 2.229(3) to 2.371(5) Å, respectively. The most striking structural feature of 2 is the further linkage of 1-D zigzag chains by 2a clusters. As shown in d, two neighboring parallel 1-D chains can be interlinked by 2a through sharing four bridging O atoms, resulting in the formation of a 2-D zigzag layer (e,f). These 2-D layers stacked in parallel along the a axis with the interlayer distance of about 3.0 Å (Figure S3), and the interspace is filled with lattice water molecules.

elements.content: The Ge–V–O clusters with [Ge2n V18‑n O42(OH)2n ] are mainly derived from the {V18O42} cluster (a) by replacing n VO5 square pyramids with n Ge2O7 groups. The replacement of two/three VO5 pyramid of {V18O42} cluster with two/three Ge2O7 groups would result in the formation of cluster {Ge4V16O42(OH)4}/{Ge6V15O42(OH)6} (b,c). The {Ge4V16O42(OH)4} cluster has D 2 symmetry while the {Ge6V15O42(OH)6} has D 3 symmetry. The Ge–V–O clusters with four Ge2O7 groups exhibit two types of configuration so far, namely, β-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} cluster (d) with D 4h symmetry and α-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} cluster (e) with S 4 symmetry. The [Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]10– in 1 belongs to α-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} configuration. However, the [Ge8V12O42(OH)6]10– cluster (f) in 2 is a new member of the {Ge8V12O40(OH)8} clusters with four Ge2O7 groups and was observed first. The structure of the [Ge8V12O42(OH)6]10– cluster in 2 can be derived from α-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} or β-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} by about 45° rotation of the top or bottom {V2O6(Ge2O7)2} fragment around the vertical axis of the equatorial eight-ring. Such a configuration could be considered as a new isomer of {Ge8V12O40(OH)8} clusters, and we designated it in this work as a γ-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} cluster. Further incorporation of TM ions on the {Ge8V12O40(OH)8} skeleton may produce a series of TM-substituted vanadogermanates such as [(en)2Cd2Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]6– in 1, [(en)4Cd4Ge8V10O38(OH)8]4–, and [Cd2(en)2Ge8V12O42(OH)6]6– in 2 (g–i). It is noteworthy that [(en)4Cd4Ge8V10O46]12– is the largest number of TM-substituted vanadogermanates currently. In addition, a common structural feature in 1–2 is that the GeO4 tetrahedra on the cluster tend to share vertexes with either themselves from neighboring clusters or TM complexes, making the isolated Ge–V–O clusters undergo further aggregation. However, the related As–V–O/Sb–V–O clusters that derived from {V18O42} replacing VO5 square pyramids with As2O5/Sb2O5 groups cannot undergo further linking, because the lone electron pairs on As3+/Sb3+ effectively terminate the structure. Thus, it is reasonable to prepare a series of vanadogermanates including a 1-D chain and a 2-D layer by using {Ge8V12O40(OH)8} clusters as structural building units.
elements.clean_text:
Structure Relations of Ge-V-O Clusters Derived from the {V18O42} Shell

The Ge-V-O clusters with [Ge2n V18-n O42(OH)2n ] are mainly derived from the {V18O42} cluster (a) by replacing n VO5 square pyramids with n Ge2O7 groups. The replacement of two/three VO5 pyramid of {V18O42} cluster with two/three Ge2O7 groups would result in the formation of cluster {Ge4V16O42(OH)4}/{Ge6V15O42(OH)6} (b,c). The {Ge4V16O42(OH)4} cluster has D 2 symmetry while the {Ge6V15O42(OH)6} has D 3 symmetry. The Ge-V-O clusters with four Ge2O7 groups exhibit two types of configuration so far, namely, β-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} cluster (d) with D 4h  symmetry and α-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} cluster (e) with S 4 symmetry. The [Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]10- in 1 belongs to α-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} configuration. However, the [Ge8V12O42(OH)6]10- cluster (f) in 2 is a new member of the {Ge8V12O40(OH)8} clusters with four Ge2O7 groups and was observed first. The structure of the [Ge8V12O42(OH)6]10- cluster in 2 can be derived from α-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} or β-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} by about 45° rotation of the top or bottom {V2O6(Ge2O7)2} fragment around the vertical axis of the equatorial eight-ring. Such a configuration could be considered as a new isomer of {Ge8V12O40(OH)8} clusters, and we designated it in this work as a γ-{Ge8V12O40(OH)8} cluster. Further incorporation of TM ions on the {Ge8V12O40(OH)8} skeleton may produce a series of TM-substituted vanadogermanates such as [(en)2Cd2Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]6- in 1, [(en)4Cd4Ge8V10O38(OH)8]4-, and [Cd2(en)2Ge8V12O42(OH)6]6- in 2 (g-i). It is noteworthy that [(en)4Cd4Ge8V10O46]12- is the largest number of TM-substituted vanadogermanates currently. In addition, a common structural feature in 1-2 is that the GeO4 tetrahedra on the cluster tend to share vertexes with either themselves from neighboring clusters or TM complexes, making the isolated Ge-V-O clusters undergo further aggregation. However, the related As-V-O/Sb-V-O clusters that derived from {V18O42} replacing VO5 square pyramids with As2O5/Sb2O5 groups cannot undergo further linking, because the lone electron pairs on As3+/Sb3+ effectively terminate the structure. Thus, it is reasonable to prepare a series of vanadogermanates including a 1-D chain and a 2-D layer by using {Ge8V12O40(OH)8} clusters as structural building units.

elements.content: In the PXRD patterns of 1 and 2 (Figures S4, Supporting Information), the good accordance between the experimental patterns and the simulated ones indicates good phase purities. The optical diffuse-reflection spectra of 1 and 2 were measured at room temperature using BaSO4 as a standard reference. Based on the Kubelka–Munk eq (1 – R)­(1 – R)/2R = α/S, where α is the K-M absorption coefficient, S is the K-M scattering coefficient, R is relative reflectance to BaSO4, and the band gap E g value can be determined by extrapolation from the linear portion of the absorption edge in a α/S versus energy plot. As shown in Figures S5–S6, the band gaps of 1 and 2 are about 2.25 and 2.00 eV, respectively, which indicate that they are both potential semiconductors. The absorption bands around 550 nm in 1 and 2 are assigned to the d–d transition of the V4+ ions. The brown color of the two crystals just arises from the absorption of the d–d transition bands. The IR spectra of 1 and 2 are shown in Figures S7. The stretching bands of NH2 and CH2 groups are observed at 3345–3310 cm–1 and 2975–2867 cm–1, and their bending bands at 1580–1605 and 1340–1458 cm–1, respectively. These signals confirm the presence of amino groups in 1 and 2. The broad band at 3460–3391 cm–1 can be assigned to the OH stretching. The strong peaks at 1015–917 cm–1 can be attributed to the stretching vibrations of VO bonds, whereas the strong peaks at 890–748 cm–1 may be due to the Ge–O stretching vibration of the GeO4 tetrahedra. These results are consistent with their single-crystal structural analysis. The TGA curves of 1 and 2 are shown in Figure S8. For 1, the weight loss from 30 to 100 °C is 1.28%, which is assigned to the loss of two lattice water molecules (1.23%). After 100 °C, a gradual weight loss of 11.40% until 470 °C is approximately attributable to the removal of five en molecules and two coordinated water ligands. For 2, the first weight loss of 5.80% between 30 and 145 °C is assigned to the release of ten lattice water molecules (calcd: 5.76%). The second weight loss of 13.63% from 145 to 550 °C corresponds to the removal of seven en ligands (calcd: 13.44%).

PXRD, UV-vis, IR, and TGA Characterizations

In the PXRD patterns of 1 and 2 (Figures S4, Supporting Information), the good accordance between the experimental patterns and the simulated ones indicates good phase purities. The optical diffuse-reflection spectra of 1 and 2 were measured at room temperature using BaSO4 as a standard reference. Based on the Kubelka-Munk eq (1 - R)(1 - R)/2R = α/S, where α is the K-M absorption coefficient, S is the K-M scattering coefficient, R is relative reflectance to BaSO4, and the band gap E  g  value can be determined by extrapolation from the linear portion of the absorption edge in a α/S versus energy plot. As shown in Figures S5-S6, the band gaps of 1 and 2 are about 2.25 and 2.00 eV, respectively, which indicate that they are both potential semiconductors. The absorption bands around 550 nm in 1 and 2 are assigned to the d-d transition of the V4+ ions. The brown color of the two crystals just arises from the absorption of the d-d transition bands. The IR spectra of 1 and 2 are shown in Figures S7. The stretching bands of NH2 and CH2 groups are observed at 3345-3310 cm-1 and 2975-2867 cm-1, and their bending bands at 1580-1605 and 1340-1458 cm-1, respectively. These signals confirm the presence of amino groups in 1 and 2. The broad band at 3460-3391 cm-1 can be assigned to the OH stretching. The strong peaks at 1015-917 cm-1 can be attributed to the stretching vibrations of VO bonds, whereas the strong peaks at 890-748 cm-1 may be due to the Ge-O stretching vibration of the GeO4 tetrahedra. These results are consistent with their single-crystal structural analysis. The TGA curves of 1 and 2 are shown in Figure S8. For 1, the weight loss from 30 to 100 °C is 1.28%, which is assigned to the loss of two lattice water molecules (1.23%). After 100 °C, a gradual weight loss of 11.40% until 470 °C is approximately attributable to the removal of five en molecules and two coordinated water ligands. For 2, the first weight loss of 5.80% between 30 and 145 °C is assigned to the release of ten lattice water molecules (calcd: 5.76%). The second weight loss of 13.63% from 145 to 550 °C corresponds to the removal of seven en ligands (calcd: 13.44%).

elements.content: Variable-temperature magnetic behaviors for 1 and 2 have been measured at 2–300 K in an external field of 1 kOe ( and ). At room temperature, the experimental χm T values are 1.67 and 2.77 cm3 K mol–1 per formular unit, respectively, being much lower than the theoretical value of 4.5 cm3 K mol–1 for 12 uncoupled V4+ ions considering g = 2.00. Upon cooling, the χm T values of 1 decreases smoothly to 1.12 cm3 K mol–1 at 30 K. On cooling, the χm T value of 2 decreases abruptly, reaching a minimum of 0.39 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. For 2, the χm T value shows a continuous decrease from 2.77 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K to 0.27 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. These behaviors suggest the presence of overall antiferromagnetic interactions within the clusters in the two cases, and are similar to that observed in [(en)2Cd2As8V12O40] and [Zn2(dien)3]­As6V15O42(H2O)]. From the structural view of point, the distances between the V···V pairs with double O bridges (2.892–3.048 Å for 1 and 2.828–3.139 Å for 2) are in the range expected for strong antiferromagnetic coupling. Therefore, antiferromagnetic couplings observed in the two compounds are not unexpected. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility 1/χm obeys the Curie–Weiss law above 2 K for 1 and above 24 K for 2 with C = 1.52 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −23.00 K for 1 and C = 4.76 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −208.9 K for 2, respectively, which further verify the presence of the antiferromagnetic couplings between V4+ ions in the two cases.

Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature magnetic behaviors for 1 and 2 have been measured at 2-300 K in an external field of 1 kOe ( and ). At room temperature, the experimental χm T values are 1.67 and 2.77 cm3 K mol-1 per formular unit, respectively, being much lower than the theoretical value of 4.5 cm3 K mol-1 for 12 uncoupled V4+ ions considering g = 2.00. Upon cooling, the χm T values of 1 decreases smoothly to 1.12 cm3 K mol-1 at 30 K. On cooling, the χm T value of 2 decreases abruptly, reaching a minimum of 0.39 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. For 2, the χm T value shows a continuous decrease from 2.77 cm3 K mol-1 at 300 K to 0.27 cm3 K mol-1 at 2 K. These behaviors suggest the presence of overall antiferromagnetic interactions within the clusters in the two cases, and are similar to that observed in [(en)2Cd2As8V12O40] and [Zn2(dien)3]As6V15O42(H2O)]. From the structural view of point, the distances between the V⋅⋅⋅V pairs with double O bridges (2.892-3.048 Å for 1 and 2.828-3.139 Å for 2) are in the range expected for strong antiferromagnetic coupling. Therefore, antiferromagnetic couplings observed in the two compounds are not unexpected. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility 1/χm obeys the Curie-Weiss law above 2 K for 1 and above 24 K for 2 with C = 1.52 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -23.00 K for 1 and C = 4.76 cm3 K mol-1 and θ = -208.9 K for 2, respectively, which further verify the presence of the antiferromagnetic couplings between V4+ ions in the two cases.

elements.content: We have successfully prepared two novel vanadogermanates under hydrothermal conditions. The cluster anions in these two compounds are derived from the {V18O42} parent cluster by substitution of four VO5 square pyramids by four Ge2O7 groups. The cluster anion in 2 is a new configuration of Ge–V–O clusters with four Ge2O7 groups, which is first reported here. Furthermore, 1 is a 1-dimensional chain based on the linkage of centrosymmetric dimeric Ge–V–O clusters {[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]}2 12– and trinuclearity [Cd3O4(en)4(H2O)2]2– complexes. 2 is an unprecedented 2-D network built from unique Ge–V–O clusters {[Cd­(en)]2[Ge8V12O42(OH)6]}8– and 1-D coordination chains {Cd3O2(en)5}2+. Magnetic measurement illustrates that 1 and 2 have overall antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between metal ions. This work not only enriches the structural diversity of vanadogermanates but also emphasizes the great potential of linking discrete Ge–V–O or TM-substituted Ge–V–O clusters with various TM complexes to make functional solid-state materials. Further work is in progress in our group.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have successfully prepared two novel vanadogermanates under hydrothermal conditions. The cluster anions in these two compounds are derived from the {V18O42} parent cluster by substitution of four VO5 square pyramids by four Ge2O7 groups. The cluster anion in 2 is a new configuration of Ge-V-O clusters with four Ge2O7 groups, which is first reported here. Furthermore, 1 is a 1-dimensional chain based on the linkage of centrosymmetric dimeric Ge-V-O clusters {[Cd(en)]2[Ge8V12O42.5(OH)5]}2 12- and trinuclearity [Cd3O4(en)4(H2O)2]2- complexes. 2 is an unprecedented 2-D network built from unique Ge-V-O clusters {[Cd(en)]2[Ge8V12O42(OH)6]}8- and 1-D coordination chains {Cd3O2(en)5}2+. Magnetic measurement illustrates that 1 and 2 have overall antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between metal ions. This work not only enriches the structural diversity of vanadogermanates but also emphasizes the great potential of linking discrete Ge-V-O or TM-substituted Ge-V-O clusters with various TM complexes to make functional solid-state materials. Further work is in progress in our group.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of NH4VO3 (0.0234 g, 0.20 mmol), GeO2 (0.0376 g, 0.36 mmol), CdCl2·2.5H2O (0.0228 g, 0.10 mmol), en (0.1 mL), and H2O (5 mL) was stirred for 0.5 h. Then it was transferred to a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless stell autoclave and sealed. The mixture was heated at 170 °C for 4 days and then cooled to room temperature. cln_elements.content:
In the PXRD patterns of 1 and 2 (Figures S4, Supporting Information), the good accordance between the experimental patterns and the simulated ones indicates good phase purities. The optical diffuse-reflection spectra of 1 and 2 were measured at room temperature using BaSO4 as a standard reference. Based on the Kubelka–Munk eq (1 – R)­(1 – R)/2R = α/S, where α is the K-M absorption coefficient, S is the K-M scattering coefficient, R is relative reflectance to BaSO4, and the band gap E g value can be determined by extrapolation from the linear portion of the absorption edge in a α/S versus energy plot. As shown in Figures S5–S6, the band gaps of 1 and 2 are about 2.25 and 2.00 eV, respectively, which indicate that they are both potential semiconductors. The absorption bands around 550 nm in 1 and 2 are assigned to the d–d transition of the V4+ ions. The brown color of the two crystals just arises from the absorption of the d–d transition bands. The IR spectra of 1 and 2 are shown in Figures S7. The stretching bands of NH2 and CH2 groups are observed at 3345–3310 cm–1 and 2975–2867 cm–1, and their bending bands at 1580–1605 and 1340–1458 cm–1, respectively. These signals confirm the presence of amino groups in 1 and 2. The broad band at 3460–3391 cm–1 can be assigned to the OH stretching. The strong peaks at 1015–917 cm–1 can be attributed to the stretching vibrations of VO bonds, whereas the strong peaks at 890–748 cm–1 may be due to the Ge–O stretching vibration of the GeO4 tetrahedra. These results are consistent with their single-crystal structural analysis. The TGA curves of 1 and 2 are shown in Figure S8. For 1, the weight loss from 30 to 100 °C is 1.28%, which is assigned to the loss of two lattice water molecules (1.23%). After 100 °C, a gradual weight loss of 11.40% until 470 °C is approximately attributable to the removal of five en molecules and two coordinated water ligands. For 2, the first weight loss of 5.80% between 30 and 145 °C is assigned to the release of ten lattice water molecules (calcd: 5.76%). The second weight loss of 13.63% from 145 to 550 °C corresponds to the removal of seven en ligands (calcd: 13.44%).

Magnetic Properties

Variable-temperature magnetic behaviors for 1 and 2 have been measured at 2–300 K in an external field of 1 kOe ( and ). At room temperature, the experimental χm T values are 1.67 and 2.77 cm3 K mol–1 per formular unit, respectively, being much lower than the theoretical value of 4.5 cm3 K mol–1 for 12 uncoupled V4+ ions considering g = 2.00. Upon cooling, the χm T values of 1 decreases smoothly to 1.12 cm3 K mol–1 at 30 K. On cooling, the χm T value of 2 decreases abruptly, reaching a minimum of 0.39 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. For 2, the χm T value shows a continuous decrease from 2.77 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K to 0.27 cm3 K mol–1 at 2 K. These behaviors suggest the presence of overall antiferromagnetic interactions within the clusters in the two cases, and are similar to that observed in [(en)2Cd2As8V12O40] and [Zn2(dien)3]­As6V15O42(H2O)]. From the structural view of point, the distances between the V···V pairs with double O bridges (2.892–3.048 Å for 1 and 2.828–3.139 Å for 2) are in the range expected for strong antiferromagnetic coupling. Therefore, antiferromagnetic couplings observed in the two compounds are not unexpected. The temperature dependence of the reciprocal susceptibility 1/χm obeys the Curie–Weiss law above 2 K for 1 and above 24 K for 2 with C = 1.52 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −23.00 K for 1 and C = 4.76 cm3 K mol–1 and θ = −208.9 K for 2, respectively, which further verify the presence of the antiferromagnetic couplings between V4+ ions in the two cases.

metadata.title:
Two Vanadogermanates
from 1‑Dimensional Chain
to 2‑Dimensional Network Built from Di-Cd-Substituted Ge–V–O
Clusters and Transition Metal Complex Bridges
